title: 114_s2932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Patient Access to Emergency Medications Act of 2016". The Congress recognizes the importance of using controlled substances by emergency medical services agencies to provide timely care in the field for critical injuries and illnesses. The Drug Enforcement Administration has conducted few investigations related to diversion in emergency medical services, with one survey showing minimal diversions or investigations for a large number of controlled substance doses administered. Regulatory oversight is crucial to prevent diversion. Regulatory oversight is essential to prevent diversion of controlled substances in healthcare settings, including emergency medical services. Oversight should be tailored to unique care delivery models and promote uniformity in rules and enforcement. Oversight by a physician medical director is crucial for ensuring uniform rules and guidelines in emergency medical services to prevent diversion of controlled substances and accommodate different types of agencies. SEC. 312. EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES is added to Part C of the Controlled Substances Act to address regulations for emergency medical services. In this section, "emergency medical services" refer to medical response provided outside of a facility, and an "emergency medical services agency" is an organization that provides such services by ground, air, or other means. The term 'emergency medical services practitioner' refers to a licensed healthcare provider who is credentialed by a medical director of an emergency medical services agency to provide emergency medical care. The term 'medical director' refers to a physician overseeing medical operations of an emergency medical services agency, providing supervision and prescribing standing orders. The terms 'standing order' and 'verbal order' refer to written and verbal protocols for emergency medical services practitioners to administer controlled substances to individuals in need of emergency medical services. The term 'verbal order' refers to a verbal prescription for emergency medical services practitioners to administer controlled substances in emergency situations, while 'online medical direction' is verbal instructions provided by a physician to guide patient care. A 'registrant emergency medical services agency' is an agency or hospital that registers under specific guidelines. The term 'registrant emergency medical services agency' refers to an agency or hospital that registers under specific guidelines to enable emergency medical services practitioners to dispense controlled substances to ultimate users in emergency situations. The Attorney General can register emergency medical services agencies to allow practitioners to dispense controlled substances to users in emergency situations, instead of registering individual practitioners or medical directors. The Attorney General registers emergency medical services agencies for dispensing controlled substances in emergency situations, requiring a single registration per State, not per location. Guidance is tailored to recognize existing medical care delivery and oversight. The Attorney General tailors guidance for registered emergency medical services agencies to recognize existing medical care delivery and oversight, including various care delivery models. Agencies must have one or more medical directors for medical oversight. Medical oversight for registrant emergency medical services agencies requires one or more licensed physicians to oversee the provision of emergency medical services. The medical director, licensed by the State, oversees patient care and transportation decisions for emergency medical services agencies. Responsibilities include approving medical protocols and ensuring patient care quality. The medical director oversees patient care and transportation decisions for emergency medical services agencies, including approving medical protocols and ensuring quality care delivery by EMS practitioners. The medical director oversees patient care, online medical direction, drug formularies, medication dispensing, training programs, and quality improvement for emergency medical services. The medical director oversees training programs, quality improvement, and administration of controlled substances for emergency medical services practitioners. Emergency medical services practitioners in a registrant agency can administer controlled substances under the authority of a State, following standing orders or online medical direction from medical directors or licensed physicians. Emergency medical services practitioners in a registrant agency can administer controlled substances under the authority of a State, following standing orders or online medical direction from medical directors or licensed physicians, which includes verbal orders issued by medical directors in specific patient cases. Emergency medical services practitioners can receive verbal orders from the medical director in specific patient cases or during mass casualty incidents. Emergency medical services practitioners can receive verbal orders from the medical director in specific patient cases or mass casualty incidents to ensure proper care and treatment. Emergency medical services practitioners can administer controlled substances without the medical director present or providing a prescription for a known individual. Documentation requirements apply. Emergency medical services practitioners can administer controlled substances without the medical director present or providing a prescription for a known individual. Documentation requirements apply, and the agency must keep standing orders on file for review by the Attorney General upon request. Practitioners must document in the patient care chart as per agency policy. Emergency medical services practitioners must document in the patient care chart when a controlled substance is administered based on agency policy. The documentation should be made available to the Attorney General upon request. The administration of controlled substances must be documented in the patient care chart and made available to the Attorney General upon request. Emergency medical services agencies can receive controlled substances at designated locations only. Emergency medical services agencies can receive controlled substances at designated locations and are allowed to move or deliver these substances within their possession between any locations without being considered distributors under the Act. Emergency medical services agencies can store controlled substances at designated locations and are permitted to move or distribute these substances within their possession between locations without being classified as distributors under the Act. The agency is allowed to store controlled substances only at designated locations. Nothing in this section should be interpreted to suggest otherwise. Emergency medical services agencies are allowed to store controlled substances at designated locations and can move them between locations without being considered distributors. Controlled substances must only be stored at designated locations, and this section does not affect requirements under the Social Security Act or limit the Attorney General's authority to enforce controlled substance diversion.
